item.title: Part war propaganda, part comic strip, Bayeux Tapestry to return to U.K.
item.description: On a state visit, France's president announced the loan of the tapestry embroidered with scenes of the 1066 Norman invasion. It will return to the U.K. for the first time in more than 900 years.

item.title: State Department undergoes deep cuts in sweeping reorganization
item.description: The State Department is slashing hundreds of jobs in what's being called its biggest shake-up in decades — drawing sharp criticism from former diplomats who say the cuts risk gutting America's diplomatic muscle.

item.title: Next time you see a vulture picking over a carcass, say 'thank you!'
item.description: Large scavengers like vultures and hyenas do an important job in protecting human health. But studies show these creatures are on the decline, allowing for the emergence of disease.

item.title: President Trump to survey flood damage in central Texas on Friday
item.description: President Trump is expected to visit Kerr County, Texas, on Friday to survey damage from last week's catastrophic flooding and to receive updates from local officials.

item.title: How 3 Muslim sisters helped change the rules of American women's wrestling
item.description: Jamilah, Zaynah and Latifah McBryde grew up wrestling one another in Buffalo, N.Y. Coaches recognized their talent, but they couldn't wear the required wrestling singlet due to their faith.

item.title: New Hampshire judge blocks Trump birthright citizenship executive order nationwide
item.description: A federal judge in New Hampshire on Thursday blocked President Trump's executive order that attempted to end birthright citizenship, stopping it from taking effect anywhere in the U.S.

item.title: How flood sirens could have saved lives in Texas
item.description: In the wake of the deadly flash floods in Texas, state leaders are exploring whether to install more flood warning sirens. Such sirens can save lives if they're part of a larger warning system.
